executive_summary: The Child Education and Developmental Center Franchises industry has posted strong growth over the majority of the past decade. An increasing body of research supporting the benefits of early childhood education has fostered rising parental interest in education-based child care. Industry franchises provide center-based child care primarily for children younger than six, typically with a focus on promoting mathematics, literacy and language-based skills. Over the five years to 2022, industry revenue is estimated to grow an annualized 1.6% to $3.7 billion, including an increase of 2.2% in 2022 alone. Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is estimated to account for 14.5% of total industry revenue in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Demand for Quality Early Education
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the past decade, an increasing amount of research has demonstrated the significant impact that high-quality early education programs have on the future academic performance and success of children. According to a study published by the National Institute for Early Education Research (NIEER), high-quality early education programs have been proven to promote greater improvement in early language, literacy and math development.

Despite strong demand for industry services, the already high cost of child care has steadily risen, making it harder for families to afford child care. According to Child Care Aware, the average cost of center-based infant care accounts for an average of 36.0% of household income in 2019. The high cost of care has been exacerbated by families with more than one child and for families living at or below the poverty line.

Typically, franchise enterprises develop curricula rooted in a variety of educational focus areas or developmental philosophies that are implemented throughout all locations. With the increasing demand for high-quality early educational programs, industry operators have increasingly differentiated themselves through their approach to early childhood education.

Demand for the industry is also dependent on the number of children younger than six and the number of children who need after-school care, women's participation in the labor force and the overall unemployment rate. Over the past decade, demand for industry operators has also been fueled by the long-term shift in women's participation in the workforce.

Increased demand for center-based child education and developmental programs has driven existing franchise expansion and motivated more franchise enterprises to enter the industry. As demand for industry services has grown, more individuals, recognizing the opportunity, have opted to be franchisees, which has expanded the number of establishments operating in the industry. During the five-year period, the number of industry establishments has increased an annualized 0.8% to 3,432 franchise locations in 2022.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2027, the price of child day-care services is anticipated to increase, which will drive revenue growth for industry operators. Because child care is a necessary cost for many working parents, increases in price typically do not result in significant declines in demand. Therefore, the rising cost of child care is anticipated to continue driving revenue growth for industry operators.

Over the five years to 2027, legislation is expected to increasingly focus on the quality and affordability of day care as more parents struggle to afford quality care. As the price of day-care services continues growing at a faster rate than per capita disposable income, legislators will increasingly focus their legislative efforts to make high-quality care accessible to more families.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Child education and developmental centers are subject to numerous regulations and licensing requirements. Government agencies regularly review the safety of buildings, educational qualifications and training of teachers, the dietary programs, the daily curriculum and hiring practices.
In some states, child education and developmental centers affiliated with religious institutions are exempt from child-education licensing regulations.

The National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC) has established comprehensive criteria for providing quality early childhood education and care. NAEYC accreditation criteria cover a wide range of factors including teacher qualifications, staffing ratios, health and safety.

Amid the coronavirus outbreak, operators have to comply with increased safety measures instituted by the Center for Disease Control (CDC). This included capacity limits, social distancing, increased cleaning, screening procedures and the use of protective equipment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Due to the nature of industry services, which require a high level of interaction and communication between caregivers, parents and children, labor costs make up the largest expense for industry operators, accounting for an estimated 45.5% of industry revenue.

Purchases are estimated to account for 3.6% of revenue. Purchase costs includes anything bought that is used for operations on a daily basis to keep the center running. These expenses include the cost of food, beverages, furniture, toys, books, computers and other supplies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rent costs vary based on location and size
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2022, lease, rent costs are estimated to account for 3.1% total revenue for the average industry operator. Rent costs can be a significant expense for industry operators as the number of children they enroll grows.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other costs include insurance and administrative
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other expenses include legal, insurance, administrative, recruiting and other related expenses. Insurance costs in the industry have been increasing over the past five years because the size of payouts in civil negligence cases has increased.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Child Education and Developmental Center Franchises industry has a low level of capital intensity. IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, industry operators will spend $0.05 on capital investments.

The industry requires a high level of personal care and interaction; thus, wages constitute the largest expense for industry operators. Since the ratio of employees to children is often a company's largest selling point, large businesses generally hire more staff to keep the employee-to-child ratio high.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for services in the industry is primarily driven by the number of women in the workforce, per capita disposable income and the unemployment rate.

The COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak has proved to be an unprecedented disruption as the health aspect has questioned the safety of in-person services offered by industry operators. As a result, industry revenue increased as much as 15.0% in 2017 and decreased as much as 9.6% in 2020.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Industry operators are increasingly adopting the use of enterprise management software to help streamline and organize administrative information, such as enrollment schedules and waitlists, medical and immunization information, automated invoicing, mobile registration, staffing and many other aspects.

Some child education centers are introducing computer-based educational tools for children. According to the National Association for the Education of Young Children, these include the use of digital cameras, computer exercises and the internet as interactive learning tools.

FAQs.question: How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: On average, industry operators only spend an estimated 0.4% of total revenue on marketing and advertising services, indicating that the majority of operators are able to target key markets through word-of-mouth recommendations and by maintaining a superior reputation.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers?
FAQs.answer: Currently, demand for industry services is higher than supply despite increasing prices. Because of this, some parents may seek out lower cost home-based care. However, the necessity of the service and education focus commands higher prices, which has made customers less sensitive to price.

FAQs.question: How does an increase in certain age groups affect your performance?
FAQs.answer: An increase in young children increases demand for industry services. Particularly, an increase in the number of children ages 1 to 4 years old, as this age segment constitutes the vast majority of children enrolled in day care centers.

FAQs.question: How do you manage operating expenses to ensure maximum profitability?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs and rent and utilities costs are the largest cost components. Of these expenses, only wages are a variable cost and typically increase as enrollment increases. Therefore, many industry operators have kept wages low in order to minimize the cost of labor and keep profits high.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not affected significantly by changes in technology. The largest changes have been the use of software for internal management and the incorporation of computers in programs to aid child learning.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Since industry operators provide direct supervising to children, industry operators have been limited in their ability to reduce wage costs with automation. Further, wage costs are kept relatively high by government regulated staff to child ratios.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to intensifying regulations?
FAQs.answer: As the government increases regulations surrounding quality of care and implements subsidies in order to make care more accessible, regulations for the industry are expected to increase, especially in 2020 due to the outbreak of COVID-19. For many industry operators, increased regulations could result in increased costs and administrative duties.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: In order to ensure high quality care and safety of children, the industry faces many health and safety requirements. Such requirements include regulations surrounding food preparation, staff to child ratios, licensing regulations, liability insurance and facility cleanliness among many others.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Significant costs for providers are wages, rent and utilities. Larger industry operators, in order to keep staff to child ratios high, will hire additional staff, thus increasing operating costs. Other significant operating costs include toys, equipment, arts and crafts supplies, pampers and food.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: As the cost of childcare has increased, a growing number of families have struggled to afford childcare. Operators in this industry operate center-based day cares, which are typically more expensive than home-based day care services.

FAQs.question: What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area? What key markets do you operate in?
FAQs.answer: Providing services in convenient locations (e.g. where density of working parents is high) is key to the success of industry establishments.

FAQs.question: How have you ensured a loyal customer base (parents) and a kept a reputation for a high level of quality? Have you contended with negative feedback from customers?
FAQs.answer: A satisfied client base will encourage repeat customers and word-of-mouth recommendations, which will help minimize revenue fluctuations.

FAQs.question: What accreditation does your company have? What are the consequences of accreditation to your business?
FAQs.answer: Accreditation promotes the center to parents and potential employees. It can also assist in identifying and correcting any areas that could compromise care.

FAQs.question: How has rising competition affected your business? What innovations could you implement to stay competitive?
FAQs.answer: The industry contends with a high degree of competition from providers of home-based child care and unlicensed caregivers, which are typically less expensive options compared with center-based child care.

FAQs.question: How will falling unemployment benefit your company? How do you cater your services to working parents?
FAQs.answer: With high unemployment, households typically have less disposable income to spend on child care services. Moreover, with a greater number of parents and family members out of work, there is less demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? Are you able to charge higher costs for your services?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income is rising strongly, a greater number of households are better able to invest in education-focused child care, which is often priced at a premium.
